title: How to Treat a Fire Ant Sting

steps.title: Apply a cold compress for 20 minutes on, 20 minutes off.
steps.content: Apply a cold compress for 20 minutes on, 20 minutes off. A cold compress can help reduce the swelling. Hold the cold compress against the affected area for 20 minutes, then remove it and let the area rest for 20 minutes. Repeat the process until your skin feels better and is less swollen. [1] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Make a cold compress by filling a plastic bag with ice cubes. Soak a washcloth under cool running water, then wrap it around the bag of ice. Press the cloth directly against your skin.

steps.title: Use a hydrocortisone cream to relieve the itching.
steps.content: Use a hydrocortisone cream to relieve the itching. Buy hydrocortisone cream over the counter at any pharmacy or drugstore. Rub a little bit onto your skin wherever you were bitten to reduce the itchiness and irritation while it heals. [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can also use calamine lotion to treat the itchiness.

steps.title: Try rubbing the sting with a paste made from water and baking soda.
steps.content: Try rubbing the sting with a paste made from water and baking soda. This is a home remedy that may work to reduce itching, swelling, and redness. Mix equal parts baking soda and water to form a paste. Apply the paste to your bites several times a day until your symptoms get better. [3] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Take an oral antihistamine to help relieve the itching.
steps.content: Take an oral antihistamine to help relieve the itching. Any antihistamine used to treat allergies may reduce the itchiness. Take 1 pill every 8 to 12 hours as needed. [4] X Research source

steps.title: The initial pain and burning subside after 10 minutes or so.
steps.content: The initial pain and burning subside after 10 minutes or so. When a fire ant stings you, it feels a bit like a less-painful bee sting. The painful sensation goes away on its own and after that your skin starts to feel itchy. This itchiness can last for weeks after the sting. [5] X Trustworthy Source Seattle Children's Hospital Health information provided by Seattle Children's hospital. Go to source It’s normal for the swelling in the bitten area to continue increasing for the first 24 hours.

steps.title: A pimple-like pustule forms within 24 hours and disappears after 3 days.
steps.content: A pimple-like pustule forms within 24 hours and disappears after 3 days. For most people, the pustules dry up completely after a few weeks. After they dry up, they may leave a brown scar that can last for several months or longer. [6] X Trustworthy Source Seattle Children's Hospital Health information provided by Seattle Children's hospital. Go to source Don’t worry if the sting turns red after the pustule forms. This is normal and doesn’t mean it’s infected.

steps.title: No, don't pop the pustule that forms in the middle of the sting.
steps.content: No, don't pop the pustule that forms in the middle of the sting. If you pop the blister, you run the risk of it getting infected. Avoid scratching the bite, as well, as this can cause it to break and expose it to potential infection. [7] X Research source If the blister does break, cleanse the area with soapy water and monitor it for signs of infection. You can also apply an antibiotic ointment to any open stings. These ointments are available over-the-counter from most drug stores and pharmacies. If the area becomes discolored or starts leaking pus, it may be infected. Seek medical attention immediately.

steps.title: Because the fire ants inject venom into your skin.
steps.content: Because the fire ants inject venom into your skin. Fire ants use their mandibles to clamp onto your skin, then sting you and inject the venom. This is what causes the initial burning sensation and the swelling that happens afterwards. [8] X Research source Fire ant bites are generally more painful and larger in the summer, which is when fire ants have the most venom.

steps.title: It’s very rare, but it’s possible.
steps.content: It’s very rare, but it’s possible. Symptoms of a fire ant sting allergy include hives, itching and swelling in areas other than the place where you were bitten, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea, tightness in the chest and difficulty breathing, and swelling of the throat, tongue, and lips, or difficulty swallowing. If you experience any of these symptoms after being stung, get to an emergency care center or hospital immediately. Symptoms of an allergic reaction usually occur within 30 to 40 minutes of being stung. In the most severe cases, people with an allergy may experience Anaphylactic shock, which can lead to dizziness, blackout, and cardiac arrest if not treated right away. If you know yourself to be allergic to fire ant stings (or bee stings), you might already be carrying an epinephrine shot, commonly called an epi-pen (epinephrine) . Inject yourself or have a friend help you, then proceed to the hospital.

steps.title: Move out of the area if you find fire ants on your body.
steps.content: Move out of the area if you find fire ants on your body. Most stings occur when people accidentally step into or sit on a fire ant mound, disturbing hundreds of thousands of fire ants primed to defend their home. If you start seeing any fire ants on your body, the first thing to do is get up and leave the area as quickly as possible. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you feel a fire ant bite you, leave the area immediately to prevent further ants crawling on you and getting more bites.

steps.title: Remove any ants from your skin.
steps.content: Remove any ants from your skin. Fire ants clamp onto the body with their mandibles before they actually sting you. Quickly rub them off with your hand or a rag to remove them before they bite. [10] X Research source Jumping into water or running the ants under a spigot will not remove them if they have already clamped down with their mandibles. [11] X Research source If there's a chance more ants have gotten into your clothes, remove your clothes immediately.
